case_name: Tripura Administration v. Gopal Chander Dutta Choudhury

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 581 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 581 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 15,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 15, 1960 of Judicial Commissioner Tripura at Agartala in Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 4 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 15, 1960, of the judicial Commissioners companyrt, Tripura at Agartala in Civil Misc.  Writ Petition  No. 4 of 1959. Ganapathy Iyer and P. D. Menon, for the

facts.text: Gopal Chander Dutta Choudhury (respondent) was appointed a constable in the Police Force of Tripura by Superintendent of Police Agartala by order dated April 18, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal Chander Dutta Choudhury-hereinafter referred to as the respondent-was appointed a companystable in the Police Force of Tripura by the Superintendent of Police, Agartala by order dated April 18, 1954. The employment was temporary and was liable to be terminated with one months numberice.

facts.text: Appointment was temporary and liable to be terminated with one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The employment was temporary and was liable to be terminated with one months numberice. On December 6, 1957, the Superintendent of Police, acting under r. 5 of the Central Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949,

facts.text: On December 6, 1957, Superintendent of Police informed respondent that his services will be terminated with effect from 6-1-58 under r. 5 of Central Services Temporary Service Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1957, the Superintendent of Police, acting under r. 5 of the Central Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949, informed the respondent that his services will be terminated with effect from 6-1-58 A. M. The respondent presented an appeal to the Chief Commissioner against the order of termination.

facts.text: Respondent presented an appeal to the Chief Commissioner against the order of termination.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent presented an appeal to the Chief Commissioner against the order of termination. By letter dated April 11, 1958 the respondent was informed that as he was an Exconvict for theft, numberhing can be done for him.

facts.text: By letter dated April 11, 1958, respondent informed that as he was an ex-convict for theft, nothing can be done for him.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated April 11, 1958 the respondent was informed that as he was an Exconvict for theft, numberhing can be done for him. In reply to another application addressed to the Chief Commissioner the respondent was informed by letter dated May 26, 1958,

facts.text: Respondent was an ex-convict for theft.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent was informed that as he was an Exconvict for theft, numberhing can be done for him. In reply to another application addressed to the Chief Commissioner the respondent was informed by letter dated May 26, 1958,

facts.text: By letter dated May 26, 1958, respondent informed that he cannot be reemployed by the Administration as ex-convict in theft case.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to another application addressed to the Chief Commissioner the respondent was informed by letter dated May 26, 1958, that he was already informed in companynection with his previous appeal that as he was an Ex- companyvict in a case of theft he cannot be reemployed by the Administration.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Judicial Commissioner Tripura praying declaration that termination order illegal, mandamus or certiorari, reinstatement with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed in the Court of the Judicial Commissioner, Tripura, a petition for a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ declaring that the order of the Superintendent of Police terminating his service was illegal and for a writ of mandamus or a writ of certiorari directing the Chief Commissioner number to enforce the said order and for an order reinstating him in the Police Force of the Tripura Administration with retros- pective effect.

facts.text: Tripura Administration submitted that respondent being temporary employee, services lawfully terminated under r.5 Central Civil Services Temporary Service Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Tripura Administration submitted in rejoinder that the respondent being a temporary employee of the Police Force, his services were lawfully terminated under r. 5 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949. The Judicial Commissioner of Tripura held that the respondent was a temporary employee,

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner held respondent was temporary employee but termination invalid as infringed Art. 311, applied to temporary servants.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner of Tripura held that the respondent was a temporary employee, but the order terminating the respondents employment was invalid for it infringed the companystitutional guarantee of protection of public servants under Art. 311 which applied to temporary as well as permanent public servants.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner viewed termination as punishment of dismissal due to ex-convict status, based on Chief Commissioner's April 11, 1958 letter.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the judicial Commissioner, Termination of employment of a temporary servant governed by the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949, will number per se be treated as a punishment of dismissal or removal, but it is open to the Court even if an order merely of termination of employment of a temporary employee is passed to ascertain whether the order was intended to be of termination simpliciter or of dismissal entailing penal companysequences, and that the order dated April 11, 1958, of the Chief Commissioner passed in appeal clearly indicated that the order of the Superintendent of Police was one imposing penalty.

facts.text: No enquiry made before discharge, no opportunity given to show cause against termination.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that before the respondent was discharged from service numberenquiry was made as to any alleged misconduct, number was he given any opportunity of showing cause against the proposed termination of employment.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds termination of respondent's employment by Superintendent dated December 6, 1957 not in violation of Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: But it is well settled that when employment of a temporary public servant, is terminated pursuant to the terms of a companytract, he is number entitled to the protection of Art. 311 2 . As observed in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India  1  by Das, C. J., a termination of service brought about by the exercise of a companytractual right is number per se dismissal or removal,

facts.text: Termination order merely terminates service, not preceded by enquiry for misconduct etc.

anchor.surface_text: The order in terms merely terminates the service of the respondent it was number preceded by any enquiry for ascertaining whether the respondent was guilty of any misdemeanor, misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or a similar cause.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner's order on appeal recites respondent ex-convict for theft, nothing could be done.

anchor.surface_text: In the order on appeal filed to the Chief Commissioner it is recited that the respondent was an ex- companyvict for theft and therefore numberhing companyld be done for him, but the purport thereof is somewhat obscure.

facts.text: Memorandum of appeal to Chief Commissioner not tendered in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The memorandum of appeal filed before the Chief Commissioner was number tendered in evidence, and there is numberhing in the order suggesting that the employment of the respondent was terminated because he had, before he was employed on April 18, 1954, been companyvicted by a Criminal Court for theft.

facts.text: No ground to infer termination was camouflage for dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberground for inferring that the Superintendent of Police was seeking to camouflage an order of dismissal by giving it the form of termination of employment in exercise of the authority under rule 5 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules.

facts.text: Onus on employee to prove intention was dismissal, no evidence about Superintendent's intention except the order.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be, assumed that an order ex facie one of termination of employment of a tem- porary employee was intended to be one of dismissal. The onus to prove that such was the intention of the authority terminating the employment must lie upon the employee companycerned but about the intention of the Superintendent of Police there is numberevidence except the order of that authority.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the petition filed by the respondent dismissed.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Judicial Commissioner of Tripura under Art. 132 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal with a certificate granted by the judicial Commissioner of Tripura under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution. Gopal Chander Dutta Choudhury-hereinafter referred to as the respondent-was appointed a companystable in the Police Force of Tripura by the Superintendent of Police, Agartala by order dated April 18, 1954.

arguments.claim: Court is obliged to enter upon a critical investigation of the reasons which induced the authority to make the impugned order of termination, similar to enquiry under s.33 Industrial Disputes Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: No relevance; substantial difference between s.33 IDA limited prima facie enquiry for industrial peace and Art.311 constitutional protection; court only checks compliance with rules.

arguments.claim: When employment of a temporary public servant is terminated pursuant to the terms of a contract, he is not entitled to the protection of Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: But it is well settled that when employment of a temporary public servant, is terminated pursuant to the terms of a companytract, he is number entitled to the protection of Art. 311 2 . As observed in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India  1  by Das, C. J., a termination of service brought about by the exercise of a companytractual right is number per se dismissal or removal,

arguments.claim: A termination of service brought about by the exercise of a contractual right is not per se dismissal or removal.

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India  1  by Das, C. J., a termination of service brought about by the exercise of a companytractual right is number per se dismissal or removal, as has been held by this Court in Satish Chander Anand v. The Union of India  2 . x x x x x x the termination of the service did number carry with it the penal companysequences of loss of pay, or allowances under r. 52 of the Fundamental Rules.

arguments.claim: The State may terminate employment of temporary employee for misconduct etc., which would amount to dismissal attracting Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: But the State may instead of exercising its companytractual right seek to terminate the employment even of a temporary employee for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or any other disqualification, and when an order of termination of employment is passed for that purpose it would amount to dismissal or removal attracting the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution. The form in which the order is companyched is number always decisive.

arguments.claim: Form of order not decisive; court must apply two tests from Parshotam Lal Dhingra: (1) right to post, (2) evil consequences; if either, then punishment.

anchor.surface_text: In Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  1 , it was observed  at p. 863  the use of the expression terminate or discharge is number companyclusive. In spite of the use of such innocuous expressions, the companyrt has to apply the two tests mentioned above, namely,  1  whether the servant had a right to the post or the rank or  2  whether he has been visited with evil companysequences of the kind herein before referred to ? If the case satisfies either of the two tests then it must be held that the servant has been punished and the termination of his service must be taken as a dismissal or removal from service

arguments.claim: The Superintendent's order dated Dec 6, 1957 merely terminates service under contractual right, not dismissal for misconduct etc.; no prior enquiry; no evidence of punitive intention; Chief Commissioner's order obscure and not linked.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is, whether the- Superintendent of Police by order dated 1958 S. C. R. 828, 8bl.  2   1953  S. C. R. 655 , December 6. 1957, passed an order in truth one of dismissal for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or like cause or he enforced the companytractual right of the State to terminate the employment of the respondent who was a temporary employee. The order in terms merely terminates the service of the respondent it was number preceded by any enquiry for ascertaining whether the respondent was guilty of any misdemeanor, misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or a similar cause.

arguments.claim: No ground for inferring camouflage of dismissal; onus on employee to prove punitive intention, not discharged as only evidence is the order itself.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be, assumed that an order ex facie one of termination of employment of a tem- porary employee was intended to be one of dismissal. The onus to prove that such was the intention of the authority terminating the employment must lie upon the employee companycerned but about the intention of the Superintendent of Police there is numberevidence except the order of that authority.

arguments.claim: Principles from Industrial Disputes Act s.33 cases have no relevance to determining if public servant denied Art.311 protection.

anchor.surface_text: But in our view the principle of these cases under the Industrial Disputes Act dealing With termination of employment of workmen and the authority of the Tribunal to grant permission to terminate such employment evolved in the companytext of maintenance of industrial peace, has numberrelevance in deciding whether the grieved public servant was by the impugned order denied the protection of the companystitutional guarantee.

holdings.text: The termination of employment of the respondent by the Superintendent of Police by order dated December 6, 1957, was not in violation of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the judicial Commissioner that the termination of employment of the respondent by the Superintendent of Police by order dated December 6, 1957, was in violation of. Art. 311 2  of the Constitution. It is true that before the respondent was discharged from service numberenquiry was made as to any alleged misconduct, number was he given any opportunity of showing cause against the proposed termination of employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary servant's employment terminated pursuant to contract; no enquiry needed as not dismissal; follows Parshotam Lal Dhingra precedent distinguishing contractual termination from punitive dismissal.

holdings.text: The Superintendent of Police enforced the contractual right of the State to terminate the employment of the respondent who was a temporary employee, and did not pass an order of dismissal for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or like cause.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is, whether the- Superintendent of Police by order dated 1958 S. C. R. 828, 8bl.  2   1953  S. C. R. 655 , December 6. 1957, passed an order in truth one of dismissal for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or like cause or he enforced the companytractual right of the State to terminate the employment of the respondent who was a temporary employee. The order in terms merely terminates the service of the respondent it was number preceded by any enquiry for ascertaining whether the respondent was guilty of any misdemeanor, misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or a similar cause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order merely terminates service without prior enquiry into misconduct; Chief Commissioner's letter obscure and not evidence of punitive intent; no link to pre-employment conviction; applies Dhingra tests (no right to post, no evil consequences).

holdings.text: An order ex facie one of termination of employment of a temporary employee cannot be assumed to be one of dismissal; the onus to prove punitive intention lies upon the employee.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be, assumed that an order ex facie one of termination of employment of a tem- porary employee was intended to be one of dismissal. The onus to prove that such was the intention of the authority terminating the employment must lie upon the employee companycerned but about the intention of the Superintendent of Police there is numberevidence except the order of that authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence beyond the order itself of Superintendent's intention; employee failed to discharge onus; memorandum of appeal not in evidence.

holdings.text: The Court is not obliged to enter upon a critical investigation of the reasons inducing the termination order of a temporary public servant, unlike enquiries under s.33 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: But in our view the principle of these  1  1960 3 C. S. R, 441.  2  1960 3 S. C. R. 451. cases under the Industrial Disputes Act dealing With termination of employment of workmen and the authority of the Tribunal to grant permission to terminate such employment evolved in the companytext of maintenance of industrial peace, has numberrelevance in deciding whether the grieved public servant was by the impugned order denied the protection of the companystitutional guarantee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantial difference between IDA s.33 prima facie enquiry for industrial peace and constitutional Art.311 protection; court only checks rule compliance, not sanctions termination.

holdings.text: Termination of service of temporary public servant pursuant to contractual right does not amount to dismissal or removal attracting Art.311.

anchor.surface_text: But it is well settled that when employment of a temporary public servant, is terminated pursuant to the terms of a companytract, he is number entitled to the protection of Art. 311 2 . As observed in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India  1  by Das, C. J., a termination of service brought about by the exercise of a companytractual right is number per se dismissal or removal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Parshotam Lal Dhingra and Satish Chander Anand; form not always decisive but two tests apply (right to post or evil consequences); here neither applies.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to holdings that termination valid and no Art.311 violation.

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  1 , it was observed  at p. 863  the use of the expression terminate or discharge is number companyclusive. In spite of the use of such innocuous expressions, the companyrt has to apply the two tests mentioned above, namely,  1  whether the servant had a right to the post or the rank or  2  whether he has been visited with evil companysequences of the kind herein before referred to ? If the case satisfies either of the two tests then it must be held that the servant has been punished and the termination of his service must be taken as a dismissal or removal from service or the reversion to his substantive rank must be regarded as a reduction in rank and if the requirements of the rules and Art. 311, which give protection to Government servant have number been companyplied with, the termination of the service or the reduction in rank must be held to be wrongful and in violation of the companystitutional right of the servant.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. The Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: the use of the expression terminate or discharge is not conclusive; the court has to apply two tests: (1) whether the servant had a right to the post or rank, (2) whether visited with evil consequences
precedents.cited_holding: at p. 863 the use of the expression terminate or discharge is not conclusive. In spite of the use of such innocuous expressions, the court has to apply the two tests mentioned above

precedents.citation: The Chartered Bank, Bombay v. The Chartered Bank Employees Union  1

anchor.surface_text: The Chartered Bank, Bombay v. The Chartered Bank Employees Union  1  and The Management of Chandramalai Estate, Ernakulam v. Its Workmen 2  and submitted that the companysiderations which were material in deciding an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act were also relevant in adjuring the true nature of the order terminating employment of a public servant. In companysidering an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act the Tribunal has, it is true, to go into all the circumstances which led to the termination simpliciter and the employer cannot be permitted to say, that he is number bound to disclose the circumstances before the Tribunal. The form of the order is number companyclusive of the true nature of the order for it is possible that the form may be merely a camouflage for an order of dismissal for misconduct.

precedents.case_name: The Chartered Bank, Bombay v. The Chartered Bank Employees Union
precedents.cited_proposition: in applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, the Tribunal can go behind the form of the termination order to ascertain if it is camouflage for dismissal for misconduct

precedents.citation: The Management of Chandramalai Estate, Ernakulam v. Its Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: The Management of Chandramalai Estate, Ernakulam v. Its Workmen 2  and submitted that the companysiderations which were material in deciding an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act were also relevant in adjuring the true nature of the order terminating employment of a public servant. In companysidering an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act the Tribunal has, it is true, to go into all the circumstances which led to the termination simpliciter and the employer cannot be permitted to say, that he is number bound to disclose the circumstances before the Tribunal. The form of the order is number companyclusive of the true nature of the order for it is possible that the form may be merely a camouflage for an order of dismissal for misconduct. It is therefore always open to the tribunal to go behind the form and look at the substance and if it companyes to the companyclusion, for example, that though in form the order amounts to termination simpliciter it in reality cloaks a dismissal for misconduct it will be open to it to set it aside as a colourable exercise of the power.

precedents.case_name: The Management of Chandramalai Estate, Ernakulam v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: in applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, the Tribunal can go behind the form of the termination order to ascertain if it is camouflage for dismissal for misconduct

precedents.citation: The Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen  1

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen  1 , this Court pointed out that there was a substantial difference between the companysequences of number-compliance with s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and Art. 311  2  of the Constitution. Compliance with s. 33 only avoids a penalty under s. 31  1  while companypliance with Art. 311  2  makes the order of dismissal final. In a proceeding under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act the Tribunal is companycerned only to make a limited enquiry whether the proposal to terminate the employment of a workman was  1  1960 1 S. C. R. 806. prima facie, bona fide or whether the employer was guilty of victimisation or any unfair labour practice.

precedents.case_name: The Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: substantial difference between consequences of non-compliance with s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and Art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the judicial Commissioner that the termination of employment of the respondent by the Superintendent of Police by order dated December 6, 1957, was in violation of. Art. 311 2  of the Constitution. It is true that before the respondent was discharged from service numberenquiry was made as to any alleged misconduct, number was he given any opportunity of showing cause against the proposed termination of employment.
The appeal must therefore be allowed and the petition filed by the respondent dismissed.

R. 655 , December 6. 1957, passed an order in truth one of dismissal for misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or like cause or he enforced the companytractual right of the State to terminate the employment of the respondent who was a temporary employee. The order in terms merely terminates the service of the respondent it was number preceded by any enquiry for ascertaining whether the respondent was guilty of any misdemeanor, misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or a similar cause.
